publicationstmt.publisher: GLBTQ Archives, Central Connecticut State University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-07-03T10:55-0400

did.unittitle: Donna C. Stimpson Collection

repository.corpname: GLBTQ Archives, Central Connecticut State University

did.abstract: Donna Stimpson has been an activist for GLBTQ rights including domestic partnership benefits, same sex marriage, gender equality, and second parent adoption in Connecticut and nationally. She has been involved with several equality groups and continues to work in the state for civil rights. The collection includes some of her personal documents as well as newspaper and internet articles, publications, memorabilia, and general information spanning over a few decades.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Donna Stimpson, a Planning Analyst Specialist for the State of Connecticut in the Department of Mental Health and Addiction Services in Hartford, has been an avid activist for GLBTQ civil rights in the state. From serving as President (and then board member) of the National Organization of Women, CT Chapter to fighting for domestic partnership benefits for state employees and same sex marriage legislation to participating in several events for equal rights in Connecticut and nationwide, Stimpson is an important figure in Connecticut GLBTQ history. There are several materials from other organizations included in the collection such as Love Makes A Family (LMF), a grassroots political and educational organization that works for same sex marriage equality. When the law finally passed in 2008 in Connecticut, a year later on December 31, 2009, LMF felt it had completed its marriage equality work and ceased operation. Another group, Connecticut Chapter of the National Organization for Women (CT NOW), strives to impact and change attitudes, beliefs, and policies that harm all women by fighting for political, economic, and social justice through education and action. Lambda Legal, founded in 1973, is the oldest and largest legal organization in the nation dedicated to the full recognition of the civil rights of lesbians, gay men, bisexuals, transgendered people, and people with HIV and AIDS. Gay, Lesbian, and Straight Education Network, Connecticut Chapter (GLSEN) works to ensure safe schools for all students, regardless of sexual orientation and gender identity through teacher training and public policy. There are over 40 Chapters around the country, which work closely with the national staff of GLSEN to implement programs, and to keep national staff informed of local events.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: Donna C. Stimpson Collection (GLBTQ.2012.05). GLBTQ Archives. Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection contains a variety of publications, correspondence, newspaper and internet articles, and general information relating to gay and lesbian culture, same-sex marriage legislation, second parent adoption legislation, Connecticut state employee domestic partnership rights among other related issues. The material dates from 1987-2011.
